body: I'm about to merge this.
@bessbd can you please review?
Hey Grant, I'm not sure how much time I can commit to this but just to clarify, did you have to change anything when pulling this out of Kudu and into Flume? Or is this just a direct move?
Also was the RM able to generate and release the binary jar with the latest Kudu release?

> Hey Grant, I'm not sure how much time I can commit to this but just to clarify, did you have to change anything when pulling this out of Kudu and into Flume? Or is this just a direct move?

Yes, this was effectively a copy paste. I did need to remove decimal support due to an older Avro version in Flume (which I didn't want to take on changing in the initial change). Otherwise it's just package changes. 

> Also was the RM able to generate and release the binary jar with the latest Kudu release?

Yes they were.

> I did need to remove decimal support due to an older Avro version in Flume (which I didn't want to take on changing in the initial change). Otherwise it's just package changes.

Oh, bummer, but I likely would have done the same thing for now.
@mpercy Can we merge this now?

@granthenke I want to make sure this doesn't break the build. Unfortunately at work I can't download the non-Maven-central deps... would you mind checking for me that this patch didn't break morphlines somehow? What I was planning on doing was making sure the same errors that appear in the Jenkins and Travis errors on this precommit run appear on trunk without this patch, but I'd have to do that at home and I haven't had the time the past few days.
I rebased this patch to make sure I had all the latest changes, I also push the PR #306 with a dummy change to verify the current build state.
@mpercy Based on the results of #306 trunk is also failing with the morphine dependency issue.
Hmm, yeah. Alright, let's merge this and defer figuring out what is wrong with morphlines, since it looks unrelated.
Thanks for taking care of this, Grant!
Superseded by #308.
@mpercy Can you help me review?
I know it says the build failed but it's just flaky tests and PMD warnings, so this is a big improvement over straight-up build failure.

LGTM, +1!
Thank you for the patch, @mpercy .

Do we also want to bump java version or just prepare / allow for it?
Hey @bessbd, thanks for the quick review! I'm fine with bumping the Java version but let's do that in a separate PR, since this one is more of a break-fix.
Looks like org.apache.thrift:libthrift is up-to-date now, so this is no longer needed.
@bessbd can you please review?

Thank you for the patch, @lightzhao !

The idea for this change sounds good. Unfortunately, without the right justification, this code probably should not be merged. Can you please think of an alternative improvement?

When the number of files exceeds the system limit.
![4118](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/59079269/71242326-ab7dfe80-2348-11ea-8861-b28893e5f9c1.png)
Why doesn't it compile
Could you please review? @bessbd @mpercy

Hi @hackty !

Thank you for this patch! On a first read, it looks good. Can you please add a test to ensure it works correctly and to avoid future changes accidentally removing this fix?

@bessbd Thanks for your prompt reply. Two unit tests were added to ensure the correctness on the fix.

The description of two unit test:
**testRenameTrackingPolicyOnReadonlySpoolDirectory**
One supplemented to examine the mechanisation of canary (RenameTrackingPolicy is enabled so the spooldir should have the write access.)
It can pass no matter before or after the fix.

**testTrackerDirTrackingPolicyOnReadonlySpoolDirectory**
One that added to ensure the correctness on currect fix.(TrackerDirTrackingPolicy is enabled and the trackdir is different from spooldir. This time the write permission of spooldir is not necessary to the trackdir and also works well.)
It can fail before the fix and pass after the fix.
Could you please review the tests? @bessbd

Thank you for the tests and the descriptions, @hackty .
It looks good to me. I'll leave some time for @mpercy to add his comments.

> Do we need to do any testing against new Hive features?

I would like to focus on whether existing use case works or not here. All unit tests of flume-hive-sink passed on my local. I ran the tests on **flume-1.9** branch since trunk does not compile on flume-thrift-source (which is not related to this fix).

> Did you attempt to compile this against Hive3?

No. I'm working on this for [BIGTOP-3123](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BIGTOP-3123) which assumes Hadoop 2.10.0. Hive 3.x does not support Hadoop 2.x.

We are planning to upgrade Hadoop to 3.x on the release after the next. We need to upgrade Hive to 3.x for that. When I tried to compile Flume with `-Dhadoop.version=3.2.1 -Dhive.version=3.1.2` , there was compilation error on flume-hdfs-sink. I will file a JIRA later if necessary.

LGTM!
I'll commit this unless anyone objects?
Thanks for your contribution @iwasakims
Thanks, @tmgstevens.
Patch looks good to me, tests pass. Thanks for the contribution and your patience and persistence in getting this reviewed, @hackty!
Thanks for the patch!

Hi @AndreLouisCaron ,

Thank you for the PRs! I've managed to skim through them and they look like valuable changes!
Unfortunately, the build is broken and I don't think I have enough time to fix it nowadays. Would you be interested in looking into that? If you'd need any support, please don't hesitate to let me know.

@bessbd I took a quick look.  I'm not familiar with Java and the ecosystem in this project, but it looks to me like some kind of static code analysis tool is reporting too many errors in code generated by the Thrift compiler.

I tried manually fixing the code in #324.  The solution is clearly less than optimal, but I'm not sure how to do it properly.  Let's continue that discussion over there.

These are generated files and should not be manually edited. If you want to stop the warnings, better to prevent SpotBugs from running on these generated files. I'm not sure how to do it but suspect it should be controllable via the Maven build.
err, PMD

Yeah, I figured as much, but:

1) I have no idea what I'm doing;
2) I have very limited time to spend on this; and
3) I wasn't 100% sure this would even fix the build yet.

Now that we see the build passing, I'll mark this as WIP and see if I can exclude the files from the PMD checks.

After fiddling around with the PMD plug-in exclusion configuration for over 2 hours, I cannot get it to ignore violations by file and I cannot get it to ignore violations from inner classes (those with a `$` in them).

I did manage to combine a mix of some exclusions and tweaking the threshold, which seems to fix the build.

See #325.

I can ditch this PR if you like the other one better.  Let me know what you think.
Thanks @AndreLouisCaron for making this change! Looks good to me. Merging.
Closing in favor of #325.
@bessbd Now that the build is fixed, I rebased this onto the latest trunk to get a clean build :-)
Before merging, I will also set the `spotbugs.maxAllowedViolations` property to 0.

@bessbd @mpercy I rebased this and set `spotbugs.maxAllowedViolations=0`.

I have some more changes to fix PMD violations as well.  Do you want those in a new commit on the same PR or should I open a new one for those changes?

Hi @AndreLouisCaron ,
Thank you for this PR! The change looks good to me and it's fairly straightforward. Do you mind adding a test so that this improvement is not accidentally removed? (No doc edit seems necessary as this behaviour is described in the user guide.)
Fixed code style issues.

Hi @oldbelvey,

Thank you for this PR! The change looks good, but can you please explain why the change resolves the issue described in the title?

> Hi @oldbelvey,
> 
> Thank you for this PR! The change looks good, but can you please explain why the change resolves the issue described in the title?

Hello  bessbd,  the oom problem is caused by repeatedly add same value into the list. changing list to set  just preventing from adding repeated values.
And it is described more specificly  at  https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/FLUME-3325

@oldbelvey : can you please include some directions to prove this change resolves the issue?
Ie. how can I reproduce the original issue and see if it happens before applying this change and that it doesn't after applying it?

@bessbd   I don't think it's easy to reproduce.  Tho OOM happens at our production environment, where one flume agent monitored more than fifteen app's log. And as it is described at the JIRA, with one file frequently write while they others are idle, the oom will happen right after the Arraylist boom.
@rgoers would you help to review it?

HI, the execution of new FileWriter(file) will clear the positionFile, so I moved this operation to just before writing the positionFile to reduce the probability of positionFile being empty when the program crashes

Please let me know if there anything else I need to fix or explain?

I don't see how I can make heads or tails out of this commit. Although the PR was created last year it seems to be against a very old version of Flume. I do not believe 199 files need to be modified to fix whatever this problem is.

> I don't see how I can make heads or tails out of this commit. Although the PR was created last year it seems to be against a very old version of Flume. I do not believe 199 files need to be modified to fix whatever this problem is.

I agree. It looks like a merge for Flume 1.5 onto trunk. Closing this.
Done in trunk.
is there a jira that describes the goals of this PR?

I don't understand this PR. I've looked at HDFSEventSink and I cannot find the code referenced above. Furthermore adding the topic to the event makes it very likely they will remain in the event when it is passed to a Sink, which could be a KafkaSink.

I think this is intended as a follow on to FLUME-1080?

Please file a new issue in Jira for the problem and please include a test case here that fails without this fix.
Hive 3 will require Hadoop 3. Should be done on a major version.

This PR is not solving the problem reported in FLUME-2894. From what I can tell that was fixed in a different PR.  This PR purports to solve a problem where the memory channel is stopped before all the items in it are removed. The problem is, that is by design. The memory channel is not durable while others like the FileChannel are so it is ok for them to be stopped while still containing events. If this PR were to be merged it would prevent Flume from shutting down until all events can be delivered. In many cases that is not desirable as the Sink consuming events may not be able to consume them due to downstream problems and so Flume would be prevented from shutting down. For this reason I am closing this PR.

@rgoers thank you for response
If want to use some of kafka's topic, offset, timestrap, etc. properties in HDFSEventSink, it is currently impossible to do so.   So I added these attributes to KafkaChannel and passed them downstream so that they were available to all sinks using Kafka-channel  In this way, there are many scenarios. For example, some values in the data can be configured as the folder name of sink

@wanghangyu817 I am trying to understand why the HDFSEventSink would care about the topic used by the KafkaChannel. There is no guarantee that the Kafka channel was even used - they might have used the file channel.  All a channel is is a place to store the events when flume receives them until someone consumes them, so in that aspect they are just an internal component that could conceivably be changed at any time. So what is the value of the HDFSEventSink knowing information about the topic, etc that was used to temporarily store the event?

@rgoers When I need to use any kafka-related attributes in sink, I currently can't get them. As mentioned above, if I need to use some attributes in the data as part of the file name, I need to pass them from the upstream component . (of course, this part needs to be customized).
